content.value: Maximalist design is all about more is more. Go big with colours, patterns, textures and shapes to make a serious statement.

contentBlocks.caption: Tone on tone
contentBlocks.copy: Expect colour on colour on colour to be big this season. To do this well, start with a feature you love and work around it. Sea green tiles might inspire a different shade of green on the wall and a third shade in details around the mirror or accessories.

contentBlocks.caption: Create a jewel in the crown
contentBlocks.copy: If maximalist interiors make you a little nervous, start small. Incorporate colour in small spaces that see less foot traffic, such as a downstairs bathroom, walk-in robe or study. You’ll make a statement in one space without overpowering the whole home.

contentBlocks.caption: Choose patterns and colour
contentBlocks.copy: Colour doesn’t have to be restricted to big blocks on walls or tiles. Using patterns can turn a nondescript space into a feature. Geometric patterns are on-trend this season and when paired with colour make an even bigger impression.

contentBlocks.caption: Use luxe fabrics
contentBlocks.copy: One thing that makes colour even more impressive is the right fabric. Velvets, silk sand satins bring a maximalist punch to a room, particularly if they’re used to make a feature out of a certain space. Deep jewel tones such as theWarlock curtain in Lipstick create drama and draw your eye to a focal point.

contentBlocks.caption: Add an element of surprise
contentBlocks.copy: True maximalism includes surprising touches of colour and texture. Whether it’s a splash of colour to some stairs, an unexpected tile on a kitchen island, or patterns around a fireplace, it’s about little quirks that add joy to normally nondescript spaces

contentBlocks.caption: Discover the joy
contentBlocks.copy: While minimalist design is about paring everything back to its functionality, maximalist design is about experiencing joy. But, that doesn’t mean throwing all your favourite things into one space. Choose a few statement pieces, plus some colours and fabrics, then start to build the space slowly from there. When you have a solid base, you’ll be able to build a cohesive look.

content.value: A mix of Japanese and Scandinavian styles – encourages balance. Sleek lines are paired with natural, organic textures, and touches of strong colour are added to muted palettes. The result? A calm, relaxing environment that’s effortlessly liveable.

contentBlocks.caption: Outdoor connection
contentBlocks.copy: Create an inside space where you can still engage with the outside. Framing windows with Sheer Curtains so you can see outdoors, as well as Light Filtering Blinds to diffuse natural sunlight, can help increase the feeling of space and light.

contentBlocks.caption: Choose natural
contentBlocks.copy: Use relaxed, natural elements to counteract sleek countertops and straight lines. Handmade vases, offcuts of plants or trees and plenty of relaxed greenery bring a calming effect to the space.

contentBlocks.caption: Layer fabrics
contentBlocks.copy: Turn a minimal Scandi space into a Japandi space by using layers. This is easily done with window furnishings. Roller Blinds in the window recess are a functional way to block out light and bring in some privacy. Layer them with Sheer Curtains that add softness to a room. To amp up the relaxed vibe, choose a puddled finish.

contentBlocks.caption: Add a strong colour
contentBlocks.copy: Tie your Japandi styling together by using small amounts of strong colour. Dark brown or black can be a clever way to add some depth to a space without being overpowering. Whether you’re using it on small pieces of furniture, customised curtain tracks, or accessories such as plant pots, it’s a great way to ground the space.

contentBlocks.caption: Mix function with flow
contentBlocks.copy: While the Scandi trend is about paring things back so they’re entirely functional, Japandi adds some quirky elements to the mix. That could be a console table with curves instead of straight edges, adding a soft wave to a room with a S Fold curtain, or adding a splash of colour with your furniture choices.

contentBlocks.caption: Include texture
contentBlocks.copy: Organic textures add softness to marble benchtops, tiled floors and sleek furniture. Jute, rattan and linen all work brilliantly. Look for rugs, baskets, and light shades as small, impactful touches. Add window furnishings such as Roman Blinds and Sheer Curtains as different fibres that bring contrast to a space.

contentBlocks.title: The Industrial interior design trend draws inspiration from inner-city warehouses and urban lofts with sharp lines and edgy pieces, taking what was once considered grungy and transforming it with an upmarket twist.

contentBlocks.caption: Light & Dark Tones
contentBlocks.copy: Even with dark features you can add light to industrial spaces with Visionwood Venetian Blinds with clean lines. If you want to avoid harsh sunlight but don’t want to be left in a dark room, light filtering Roller Blinds fill the room with soft light and have a practical finish.

contentBlocks.caption: Noteworthy Neutrals
contentBlocks.copy: Creating a neutral colour scheme doesn't have to be boring. Focus on layering different shades and textures. Designer Curtains in either block out or sheer have plenty of shades and tones to choose from so you can find your perfect match.

contentBlocks.caption: Clean, Hard Lines
contentBlocks.copy: Clean lines are a defining feature of industrial interiors. Add additional linear features with Visionwood Venetians or Planation Shutters, or for spaces that already have hard lines, soften the look with Sheer or Block Out Designer Curtains.

contentBlocks.title: Carefree and quirky, the Bohemian interior design trend focuses on bringing the outdoors indoors, with global and vintage pieces taking pride of place.

contentBlocks.caption: Boho Vintage
contentBlocks.copy: Bohemian design lets you blend colours and styles. Pair statement items like detailed vintage vanities with crisp white Plantation Shutters or airy Sheer Designer Curtains that hint at lush gardens just a few steps away.

contentBlocks.caption: Layer Your Textures
contentBlocks.copy: Texture is everything when adding Bohemian vibes to your home. Start with Sheer Designer Curtains or Block Out Curtains then continue layering natural feeling textures like linen and wool to your room.

contentBlocks.caption: The Lived In Look
contentBlocks.copy: The key feature to achieve with boho chic is a lived in look. Nothing should look too perfect or formal. Rich textures in Designer Curtains or traditional Plantation Shutters will help you realise your bohemian dream and provide the perfect back drop for all your carefully selected pieces.

contentBlocks.title: Modern vintage interior design gives a new lease on life to pieces and styles of the past. It’s not about replicating days gone by, it’s about mixing and matching new and old pieces to add character to your home.

contentBlocks.caption: Highlight your Heroes
contentBlocks.copy: Choose pieces that are bold either in design or colour. To let them shine, surround them with pared back elements like white walls, white PolyLux® Plantation Shutters or neutral Sheer Designer Curtains.

content.value: Along with modern vintage, modern mid-century has made a comeback. Here DIY Blinds' Visionwood Venetian Blinds are a perfect match for this modern mid-century living area.
Vintage industrial pairs traditional warehouse features like these windows with an updated colour palette that includes crisp, clean whites.
Designer Curtains
add soft texture to what could otherwise be a harsh space.
PolyLux® Plantation Shutters
are ideal for modern vintage interiors, taking this colonial-era staple and updating it with a modern white finish and premium materials that won't warp or discolour. For a softer look, pair with
Sheer Designer Curtains
in a warm shade.

are ideal for modern vintage interiors, taking this colonial-era staple and updating it with a modern white finish and premium materials that won't warp or discolour. For a softer look, pair with
Sheer Designer Curtains
in a warm shade.

contentBlocks.caption: Vintage Style
contentBlocks.copy: Many vintage and period homes feature floor to ceiling curtains in a range of bold patterns. For a modern take on this design feature, Blockout Designer Curtains offer the same style, with a range of different pleats, but in a more modern palette.

contentBlocks.title: The Romance interior design trend celebrates darker moody tones with a feminine and romantic style. Bold deep colours take pride of place, while neutrals surround them to avoid feeling overwhelmed.

contentBlocks.caption: Everyday Romance
contentBlocks.copy: Add a touch of romance to your every day with feminine details throughout your home. Pair patterned tiles or whimsical wallpaper with Plantation Shutters that complement the romantic design.

contentBlocks.caption: Embrace Dark Tones
contentBlocks.copy: Set the mood with dark, rich tones. Think deep purples, reds and blues. Make a statement by painting multiple walls dark, and continue the theme with dark charcoal sheer designer curtains to complete the look.

contentBlocks.caption: Soft Finishes
contentBlocks.copy: Whether light or dark, the romance interior design trend needs a soft feminine touch. Sheer curtains offer both a soft texture and fill your room with soft filtered light. A two in one solution to complete your romantic rooms.

contentBlocks.title: While some may think a minimalist design is plain, the key to this style is simply careful consideration. Neutral tones and simple design let your favourite hero pieces shine to their fullest.

contentBlocks.caption: Clean Lines
contentBlocks.copy: Superior craftsmanship on DIY Blinds’ Plantation Shutters and Visionwood Venetian Blinds allow for clean lines for your window dressings, no matter how big or small the window is, to achieve a simple yet stylish minimalist look.

content.value: Choose one aspect in each room to hero. This study nook lets detailed panelling in the cupboards take pride of place by pairing them with understated white
Roller Blinds.
Minimalism can still embrace patterns like this herringbone tile splash-back. Rather than matching it with clashing lines from Venetian Blinds or Shutters, this kitchen uses simple
Roller Blinds
that add rather than detract from the interior.
By matching the colour of the wall to the
PolyLux® Plantation Shutters
, this room emphasises a minimalist monochromatic colour scheme, whilst the Plantation Shutters provide privacy in the bedroom.

Roller Blinds.

contentBlocks.caption: Simplicity at Its Best
contentBlocks.copy: The minimalist style lets key hero pieces speak for themselves by keeping their surroundings simple. Roller Blinds are excellent choices in rooms where geometric designs take pride of place, whilst Venetian Blinds can add pattern to rooms where the focus is on colour.

contentBlocks.title: Inspired by the American coastal town, the Hamptons interior design trend feature light and airey colours paired with white and beige pieces.

contentBlocks.caption: White & Light
contentBlocks.copy: No Hamptons home is complete without plantation shutters. White shutters have always been a favourite for these coastal homes and look stunning inside and out, especially alongside white weatherboards, another Hamptons must-have.

content.value: While Hamptons style may focus on neutrals, the key to perfecting this design trend is to add just the right amount of nautical blues and stripes.
Another feature of Hamptons homes is the abundance of natural light.
Sheer Designer Curtains
let through softly filtered light to fill your home, but also maintain daytime privacy so you can have the best of both worlds.
PolyLux® Plantation Shutters

are the ultimate upmarket coastal accessory. Not only are they reminiscent of louvre windows frequently found in coastal homes, they are also a practical solution for holiday homes. Installing plantation shutters brings holiday vibes to your home all year round.
While Hamptons style may focus on neutrals, the key to perfecting this design trend is to add just the right amount of nautical blues and stripes.
Another feature of Hamptons homes is the abundance of natural light.
Sheer Designer Curtains
let through softly filtered light to fill your home, but also maintain daytime privacy so you can have the best of both worlds.
PolyLux® Plantation Shutters

are the ultimate upmarket coastal accessory. Not only are they reminiscent of louvre windows frequently found in coastal homes, they are also a practical solution for holiday homes. Installing plantation shutters brings holiday vibes to your home all year round.

contentBlocks.caption: Natural Neutrals
contentBlocks.copy: Hamptons style is all about keeping it simple. Keep the walls white, with PolyLux® Plantation Shutters or Sheer Designer Curtains, while walls and furniture should feature light natural tones and textures. These airy staples allow simple accessories to pop.
